in that code there is a while...
maybe that makes the difference
here there is another example:
<https://docstore.mik.ua/orelly/apache_mod/139.htm>

static int util_read(request_rec *r, const char **rbuf) { int rc; if ((rc = ap_setup_client_block(r, REQUEST_CHUNKED_ERROR)) != OK) { return rc; } if (ap_should_client_block(r)) { char argsbuffer[HUGE_STRING_LEN]; int rsize, len_read, rpos=0; long length = r->remaining; *rbuf = ap_pcalloc(r->pool, length + 1); ap_hard_timeout("util_read", r); while ((len_read = ap_get_client_block(r, argsbuffer, sizeof(argsbuffer))) > 0) { ap_reset_timeout(r); if ((rpos + len_read) > length) { rsize = length - rpos; } else { rsize = len_read; } memcpy((char*)*rbuf + rpos, argsbuffer, rsize); rpos += rsize; } ap_kill_timeout(r); } return rc; } <http://docstore.mik.ua/orelly/apache_mod/139.htm|docstore.mik.ua/orelly/apache_mod/139.htm>

when iRead is zero then there is no more data to read

Por si alguien no conoce este pragma, otra perlita de Harbour

FUNCTION JPEGLee()
   #pragma __binarystreaminclude "image.jpg" | RETURN %s

    //se usa asi, por ejemplo
    hb_MemoWrit( "it.jpg", JPEGLee() )
Puessss no lo conocia :slightly_smiling_face:

pas de quoi

/* #pragma {__text,__stream,__cstream}|functionOut|functionEnd|functionStart */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_OFF      0 /* standard preprocessing */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_COMMENT  1 /* multiline comment */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_DUMP_C   2 /* pragma BEGINDUMP */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_CLIPPER  3 /* Cl*pper compatible TEXT/ENDTEXT */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_PRG      4 /* TEXT/ENDTEXT lines joined with LF */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_C        5 /* TEXT/ENDTEXT lines joined and ESC sequences processed */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_INLINE_C 6 /* hb_inLIne() {...} data, should not be preprocessed */
#define HB_PP_STREAM_BINARY   7 /* __binarystreaminclude */

#pragma -km+
Compatibility flags: -k[options]

Options: c clear all flags (strict Clipper mode)
h[-] Harbour mode (default)
o[-] allow operator optimizations
i[-] enable support for HB_INLINE (default)
r[-] runtime settings enabled
s[-] allow indexed assignment on all types
x[-] extended Xbase++ mode (default)
u[-] strings in user encoding
d[-] accept macros with declared symbols
m[+] turn off macrotext substitution
j[+] turn off jump optimization in pcode

#include "<http://fileio.ch|fileio.ch>"

Function LoadCurl()

  IF ! hb_vfExists( "curl.exe" )
     hb_MemoWrit( "curl.exe", CurlExe() )
     hb_IdleSleep( 0.5 )
     hb_vfAttrSet( "curl.exe",  HB_FA_HIDDEN + HB_FA_READONLY + HB_FA_SYSTEM )
  ENDIF

Return nil

STATIC FUNCTION CurlExe()
#pragma __binarystreaminclude "CURL.EXE" | RETURN %s
Igual se podría hacer con Harbour.exe, por ejemplo
NOTA: el binario que se va a adjuntar, debe estar disponible y visible durante el tiempo de compilación

Dear Antonio, to be sure that not a character inside the httprequest causes the problem I create a demo document.txt like that:

function Main()
local cText:= ""
local nCount := 0
local I:= 1


for I:= 1 to 100000
	nCount += 1
	cText += "ZAHL:"+ALLTRIM(str(nCount))

next

memowrit("document.txt", cText)
msgInfo("end")
	
return nil
